_comment: Created by ianb on 13/01/2014 15:17:08 using v2.0
title: How has satisfaction with social care services changed by region?
analysis_commentary:
Looking at satisfaction by region, we can see that London performs worse overall, with 57.2% of those in London being satisfied compared with the national average of 62.8% in 2011/12, and 58.2% in London compared to the national average of 63.7% in 2012/13. This a difference of 5.6 and 5.5 percentage points, respectively. Evidence suggests that there is a 'London effect' experienced in healthcare where people in London are in general less satisfied with their care compared to the rest of England. Research suggests this could be due to a younger, more transient and more ethnically diverse population in London[1-3]. This effect could be used to explain the similar results we see here in social care service satisfaction.

[1] General practice in London Supporting improvements in quality (King's Fund)
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Personal Adult Social Care Survey
